image.altText: A sign for the Launceston General Hospital and the Ashley Youth Detention Centre behind an obscured man.

items.synopsis: After 29 months, the Commission of Inquiry into the Tasmanian Government's Responses to Child Sexual Abuse in Institutional Settings has held its final hearing. Its president has called for change, saying more children will be abused without it.

title.children: Tasmanian child sex abuse inquiry refers more than 100 people to police and child protection

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Australians will cast their first referendum vote in more than two decades in October, deciding the fate of a constitutionally-enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: October 14 set as Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announces a date for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: 'The PM is ignoring us': Shadow Indigenous affairs minister says PM's proposal is 'about division'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: On voting day, sorting of pre-poll votes will begin from 4pm, meaning there will already be a chunk of votes ready for counting from 6pm when polling booths on the east coast close. Counting Yes and No for each state is much simpler than all the calculations that go into counting a federal election. A majority of Australians and a majority of states must support the constitutional change for it to succeed. That means that, if every east coast state returned a Yes vote, the night could be over quite quickly. However the vote turns out, the result should be clear sooner than a federal election.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We might have a result a lot faster than on election night

props.alt: Wide shot of a TV studio with a man sitting at a laptop.

children.content: The counting of referendum votes is unlikely to take as long as on election night.
(ABC News: Justin Stevens)
On voting day, sorting of pre-poll votes will begin from 4pm, meaning there will already be a chunk of votes ready for counting
from 6pm when polling booths on the east coast close.
Counting Yes and No for each state is much simpler than all the calculations that go into counting a federal election.
A majority of Australians and a majority of states must support the constitutional change for it to succeed.
That means that, if every east coast state returned a Yes vote, the night could be over quite quickly.
However the vote turns out, the result should be clear sooner than a federal election.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tasmania has the nation's only Liberal government, and Premier Jeremy Rockliff is one of the few Liberal Leaders to back the proposal. Will his support be enough, along with Labor and Green voters, to put the Island state in the Yes camp? Few give the proposal much chance of succeeding in Queensland, which leaves Western Australia. With Labor riding high in the state in recent years, and the collapse in Liberal support, there had been hopes from Yes campaigners that the state could be enticed to vote Yes. Hopes have dimmed with the retirement of premier Mark McGowan and the recent controversy over the now-repealed Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act. The votes of the two territories add to the national totals, but do not form part of the majority of states equation. The ACT is expected to vote Yes, having been the only Jurisdiction to vote for the Republic in 1999.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If the referendum passes in NSW, Vic and SA, which fourth state might vote Yes?

children.content: Tasmania has the nation's only Liberal government, and Premier Jeremy Rockliff is one of the few Liberal Leaders to back the proposal.
Will his support be enough, along with Labor and Green voters, to put the Island state in the Yes camp?
Few give the proposal much chance of succeeding in Queensland, which leaves
Western Australia
With Labor riding high in the state in recent years, and the collapse in Liberal support, there had been hopes from Yes campaigners that the state could be enticed to vote Yes.
Hopes have dimmed with the retirement of
premier Mark McGowan
and the recent controversy over the now-repealed
Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Act
The votes of the two territories add to the national totals, but do not form part of the majority of states equation.
The
ACT
is expected to vote Yes, having been the only Jurisdiction to vote for the Republic in 1999.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Joining Jacinta Nampijinpa Price in Hobart, No campaign spokesman and Bundjalung man Nyunggai Warren Mundine has delivered a fiery condemnation of the PM for kicking off the "divisive" Voice debate. "This thing is about division and dividing this country, and the racial abuse that we've been hearing over the last few months," he says. "It's all Albo. He's the one who's started this, he's the one who brought it out, and if he thinks that the answer to fixing everything is [a] magic wand, then he's not answering the real question, [which is] how do we help people who are having tremendous problems in Aboriginal communities out there." Mr Mundine says he and his family "fought to be treated the same as every other Australian", and Australia is no longer a racist country. "I will swear on my mother's and father's grave that I will fight this, and I'll be out there every day championing the wonderful country that we got, which is not a racist group of people," he says. "We're not a racist country, which all these elite corporate people and football codes and everyone say we are."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warren Mundine says he will oppose Voice on his 'mother's and father's grave'

props.alt: A middle-aged Aboriginal man gestures as he speaks in front of a bookshelf on the ABC News channel.

children.content: No campaign leader Nyunggai Warren Mundine.
(ABC News)
Joining Jacinta Nampijinpa Price in Hobart, No campaign spokesman and Bundjalung man
Nyunggai Warren Mundine
has delivered a fiery condemnation of the PM for kicking off the "divisive" Voice debate.
"This thing is about division and dividing this country, and the racial abuse that we've been hearing over the last few months," he says.

"It's all Albo. He's the one who's started this, he's the one who brought it out, and if he thinks that the answer to fixing everything is [a] magic wand, then he's not answering the real question, [which is] how do we help people who are having tremendous problems in Aboriginal communities out there."
Mr Mundine says he and his family "fought to be treated the same as every other Australian", and Australia is no longer a racist country.
"I will swear on my mother's and father's grave that I will fight this, and I'll be out there every day championing the wonderful country that we got, which is not a racist group of people," he says.
"We're not a racist country, which all these elite corporate people and football codes and everyone say we are."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In terms of Australia, Craig Vardy, head of fixed income, BlackRock Australasia, does not see a recession here. "Australia may get through without a recession." He notes that the Reserve Bank wants to avoid a recession, and says banks have enough capital to manage higher defaults by mortgage borrowers. "They've got some credibility to build back after the some of the communication errors they've had." "The last thing they want to see is a recession here." "And hence why they've been slower than the RBNZ (in terms of raising interest rates)." Mr Vardy says the RBA wants to keep full employment so they will on the "backfoot" when it comes to raising rates. However, he thinks there is a 50 per cent chance that the RBA will raise interest rates from the current level of 4.1 per cent by February next year, possibly in November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BlackRock sees one more RBA rate rise

children.content: In terms of Australia,
Craig Vardy, head of fixed income, BlackRock Australasia
, does not see a recession here.
"Australia may get through without a recession."
He notes that the Reserve Bank wants to avoid a recession, and says banks have enough capital to manage higher defaults by mortgage borrowers.
"They've got some credibility to build back after the some of the communication errors they've had."
"The last thing they want to see is a recession here."
"And hence why they've been slower than the RBNZ (in terms of raising interest rates)."
Mr Vardy says the RBA wants to keep full employment so they will on the "backfoot" when it comes to raising rates.
However, he thinks there is a 50 per cent chance that the RBA will raise interest rates from the current level of 4.1 per cent by February next year, possibly in November.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I've just been at a briefing by the world's biggest investment manager BlackRock on their mid year outlook. Here's what they see: Holding Tight: in terms of global inflation coming down and the end of central bank rate hikes, BlackRock's Asia-Pacific chief investment strategist Ben Powell says "we are not there yet." He says central banks won't start to reduce interest rates anytime soon because supply constraints remain high, which is keeping services inflation higher. Mr Powell says it would be "expensive mistake" for central banks to declare victory over inflation too early. "If you re-raise that can cost you years of credibility." "With inflation, yes again, it's come down, that's great, that's important, we're hopefully on the right path, but we're just not there yet so declaring victory too soon would be a mistake." He says high interest rates have returned and the period of low interest rates was likely an aberration. And Mr Powell doesn't rule out the risk of a global recession because of high interest rates slowing economic growth. "In the recent weeks....there has been more hope around no landing." "We still think there is going to be a landing over the next several quarters caused by the long and variable lags of interest rate policy." "It still seems likely to us that taking interest rates, say in the US, up by 500 basis points from the old regime to the new regime from an unbelievably low level by historical standards to a much higher level frankly has some consequences." But Mr Powell doesn't want to use the R-word. He sees "an economic outlook a little bit more negative than the current market expectation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BlackRock says risk of 'landing' for global economy

children.content: I've just been at a briefing by the world's biggest investment manager
BlackRock
on their mid year outlook.
Here's what they see:
Holding Tight:
in terms of global inflation coming down and the end of central bank rate hikes,
BlackRock's Asia-Pacific chief investment strategist Ben Powell
says "we are not there yet."
He says central banks won't start to reduce interest rates anytime soon because supply constraints remain high, which is keeping services inflation higher.
Mr Powell says it would be "expensive mistake" for central banks to declare victory over inflation too early.
"If you re-raise that can cost you years of credibility."
"With inflation, yes again, it's come down, that's great, that's important, we're hopefully on the right path, but we're just not there yet so declaring victory too soon would be a mistake."
He says high interest rates have returned and the period of low interest rates was likely an aberration.
And Mr Powell doesn't rule out the risk of a global recession because of high interest rates slowing economic growth.
"In the recent weeks....there has been more hope around no landing."
"We still think
there is going to be a landing over the next several quarters
caused by the long and variable lags of interest rate policy."

"It still seems likely to us that taking interest rates, say in the US, up by 500 basis points from the old regime to the new regime from an unbelievably low level by historical standards to a much higher level frankly has some consequences."
But Mr Powell doesn't want to use the R-word.
He sees "an economic outlook a little bit more negative than the current market expectation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you weren't tuned into News Breakfast this morning you would have missed Flight Centre boss Graham Turner discussing the Qantas-Qatar Airways debacle that's playing out right now. A quick recap, if you haven't been paying complete attention to the story: The federal government rejected an application from Qatar Airways for more flights, saying it was not in the national interest Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones said the decision was also to help keep Qantas profitable Qantas CEO Alan Joyce said on Monday allowing extra flights by Qatar would distort the market Virgin Australia boss Jayne Hrdlicka said the decision would keep airfares higher Mr Turner says the decision will hurt travellers who are already faced with high airfare prices because of a lack of available seats to meet international travel demand. He's told News Breakfast's Madeleine Morris that the government's move to block the flights was "not in the national interest" and the real reason behind it needs to be clearly explained. You can watch his full chat below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Flight Centre CEO says Qatar Airways decision 'not in the national interest'

children.content: If you weren't tuned into News Breakfast this morning you would have missed
Flight Centre boss Graham Turner
discussing the Qantas-Qatar Airways debacle that's playing out right now.
A quick recap, if you haven't been paying complete attention to the story:
The federal government rejected an application from Qatar Airways for more flights, saying it was not in the national interest
Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones said the decision was also to help keep Qantas profitable
Qantas CEO Alan Joyce said on Monday allowing extra flights by Qatar would distort the market
Virgin Australia boss Jayne Hrdlicka said the decision would keep airfares higher
Mr Turner says the decision will
hurt travellers
who are already faced with
high airfare prices
because of a
lack of available seats
to meet international travel demand.
He's told News Breakfast's Madeleine Morris that the government's move to block the flights was
"not in the national interest"
and the real reason behind it needs to be clearly explained.
You can watch his full chat below:
